question: Question_07_(a)
statement:
Suppose that \emph{A} is a symmetric 4x4 matrix with eigenvalues 0, 1,
4, 5. Define a sequence of vectors $\mathbf{x}_n \in \mathbb{R}^{4}$ by
choosing \textbf{x}\textsubscript{0} at random, and then settings

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{y}_n &= (A-3I)^{-1}\mathbf{x}_{n-1} \\
\mathbf{x}_n &= \mathbf{y}_n/\|\mathbf{y}_{n}\|
\end{align*}

for \emph{n = 1, 2, ...}. You then observe that
\textbf{x}\textsubscript{n} converges to

\[\mathbf{x}_\infty = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2, 1/2]^T\]

as $n \to \infty$.

\textbf{(a)} What is $A\mathbf{x}_\infty$?
sols:
Using the hints, we know that $\displaystyle \mathbf{x}_{\infty}$ is the
eigenvector associated to the largest eigenvalue of the matrix
$\displaystyle (A - 3I)^{-1}$.

The eigenvalues of $\displaystyle A-3I$ are the eigenvalues of \emph{A}
shifted by 3, with the same eigenvectors. We can see this by noting for
each eigenvector \emph{v} of \emph{A}, we have

\[\displaystyle 
(A-3I)v = Av - 3v = \lambda v - 3v = (\lambda - 3)v\]

Since \emph{A} has the eigenvalues \emph{λ\textsubscript{0} = 0},
\emph{λ\textsubscript{1} = 1}, \emph{λ\textsubscript{2} = 4} and
\emph{λ\textsubscript{3} = 5}, the matrix $\displaystyle A - 3I$ has the
eigenvalues \emph{η\textsubscript{0} = -3}, \emph{η\textsubscript{1} =
-2}, \emph{η\textsubscript{3} = 1} and \emph{η\textsubscript{4} = 2}.
Next, the eigenvalues of the inverse $\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}$ are the
reciprocal of the original eigenvalues, with the same eigenvectors.
Hence the eigenvalues of $\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}$ are
\emph{γ\textsubscript{0} = -1/3}, \emph{γ\textsubscript{1} = -1/2},
\emph{γ\textsubscript{3} = 1} and \emph{γ\textsubscript{4} = 1/2}. We
see that the dominating eigenvalue of $\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}$ is
\emph{γ\textsubscript{3} = 1}, and therefore, by the power method,
$\mathbf{x}_\infty$ is an eigenvector of $\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}$
with eigenvalue \emph{1}.

This means that $\mathbf{x}_\infty$ is also an eigenvector of \emph{A}
with eigenvalue \emph{λ\textsubscript{2} = 4}. In other words,

\[\displaystyle 
A\mathbf x_{\infty} = 4 \mathbf x_{\infty} = [2,2,2,2]^{T}\]
hints:
In the power iteration procedure, the convergent vector
$\displaystyle x_{\infty}$ is the eigenvector corresponding to the
largest eigenvalue of the matrix in question. In this question the
matrix is $\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}$

The eigenvalues of $\displaystyle A-3I$ are the eigenvalues of \emph{A}
shifted by 3. For the inverse matrix, take the inverse of these
eigenvalues. Find the eigenvalue of $\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}$ with the
largest absolute value, as well as the corresponding eigenvalue of
\emph{A}.
